description: Students focus on the natural history of Upper Midwest vertebrates and phylogenetic,
morphological, and functional relationships of these animals. Laboratories include
identification, and morphology. During field trips, students document bird migrations,
amphibian chorusing, and other animal activities. Independent projects explore topics
ranging from blue bird nesting behavior to thermal conductivity and insulation in
animals. Students attend lectures plus one three-hour laboratory per week. Offered annually.
Counts as "comparative organismal biology" core category. Prerequisites: BIO 150.
